MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the sequencer, retrograde and landing lesson.

In this lesson, we will cover the Sequence Programmer - a system responsible for the event sequencer of the capsule. We will then use the knowledge to execute a retrograde burn with a splashdown in the Atlantic ocean.
First of all, the sequencer handles all automatic events and the ASCS modes by providing power to various electrical systems.
The Programmer controls the Sequence System - the system that controls all the major events and states a mission consists of.
It has a simple user interface where a column of indicators displays the current state.
The indicators is a list of lights on the left side of the panel. Each light has three states. Unlit, Normal and Pending.
Unlit means that the event has not yet happened, or isn't relevant anymore.
Normal is indicated by a green light and means the event executed normally.
Pending is indicated by a red light and means that the event is about to happen, is processing, or has failed. The light will switch to green when completed. Failures will remain red.
Let's quickly go through what each indicator represents.
JETT TOWER indicates that the tower is about to be jettisoned. It will illuminate RED a few seconds before jettison, and turn to green if jettison is OK.
CAPSULE SEP will illuminate RED a few seconds before capsule separation from the LV. It will turn green if separation is OK.
RETRO SEQ will turn red when the retro sequence has started, and green when completed. It is started when the TIME TO RETRO timer reaches 0, or the execute button next to the light is pressed.
Retrograde is what enables you to fire the retro engines for reentry. The retro sequence will normally start 40 seconds before ignition.
The RETRO DELAY switch in NORM means the RETRO FIRE sequence will start 40 seconds after RETRO SEQ illumination, or else instantly (INST).
The RETRO ATT indicator shows you are in the correct attitude required for automatic retro fire. It will not fire automatically if the capsule is outside the range of retro attitude.
This is important as burning the retro engines in the wrong direction may make it impossible to get back to Earth. Red is outside correct attitude, green is inside correct attitude.
The retro attitude switch can be use to BYPASS the retro attitude requirement. This is useful if there are malfunctions in the gyros, attitude, or ASCS systems.
FIRE RETRO will be red 10 seconds before retro engines are fired. The retros can be manually fired by pressing the button next to the light. It will be green when FIRE RETRO is completed.
On the other side of the panel, the RETRO WARN and TONE will indicate that the RETROs are about to start. Cancel if something is wrong!
60 seconds after RETRO FIRE, the retro engines will be jettisoned. RETRO JETT will be red two seconds before jettison and green if jettison was OK.

After RETRO JETTISON, place the ATTITUDE SELECT switch to REENTRY so ASCS can position the capsule to the reentry attitude automatically. Do this now to learn how the craft reacts. Always be prepared to help the ASCS with manual attitude control, especially when setting this switch.
.05g will illuminate when deceleration is detected. ASCS will set the capsule into a roll for a more stable reentry.
DROGUE can be manually deployed by pressing the button next to the DROGUE indicator. The programmer will deploy this automatically at an altitude of 21.000 ft.
SNORKEL will let outside air enter the cabin and set the O2 EMER mode on. A tone and indicator will indicate this. This will automatically open after drogue deploy.
MAIN will deploy the MAIN chutes. You can manually deploy this by using the button next to the indicator. This accounts for the RESERVE too if the MAIN chute fails.

LANDING BAG will illuminate when the landing bag is extended, making the capsule ready for impact and landing. A switch next to the button in AUTO will deploy it automatically 5 seconds after MAIN CHUTE, or instantly at MAN.
RESCUE indicates that your rescue equipment is deployed. The switch can be positioned so it is deployed at splashdown automatically, or instantly in MAN.
A set of fuses gives you more control too, look at the description of them to learn what they do. For the programmer to be in operation, ensure the fuse is set to 1 or 2.
Set the attitude back to retro. The ASCS system will automatically maneuver the craft to the retrograde attitude.
The next part of this lesson will take you through a retrograde burn, reentry and splashdown.
The Retrograde Time shows when the retrograde sequence will start, and the Time to Retrograde timer below is currently counting down towards it.
The handle on the satelitte clock can be used to modify the planned retroequence time.
Use time scale to about 30 minutes before retrograde.
We now need to reconfigure the capsule for the retrograde burn. Open the Mission Pad -> Checklists -> Entry: PRE-RETRO (TR -30).
RUN the checklist.

30 minutes before retrograde, the checklist will ask you to configure the temperature settings to maximum cooling. This is to cold soak the cabin before entry. This is because the temperatures will rise during reentry. Follow the next 3 steps, then press ROGER when you have set these.
Use time scale to 15 minutes before retrograde, then press ROGER to continue the lesson.

The checklist will now ensure that needed fuses and systems are set up to ignite the retrograde engines. It will also ensure that the retrograde engines can't be jettisoned. Complete the steps, and press CLEAR ALL when the "Maintain Retro Attitude" manual step is flashing.
Excellent. The next checklist we need to follow is the actual retrograde burn checklist. Most should be automatic. RUN the Mission Pad -> Checklists -> Entry: RETRO checklist.
We will now use the Time to Retrograde timer along with the Checklist Guidance System to verify that the correct sequencer events happens.
5 minutes before the retrograde sequence starts, the "5 MIN TO RETROGRADE" light on the Satellite Clock will illuminate. Press ROGER when it is illuminated.

The next event will be the start of our retro sequence. During retro sequence, you can use the seconds-handle of the Satellite Clock. The outer marks on the clock can be use to time things. Use timescale until retrosequence starts.
The retro sequence is starting, and the retro sequence light should be green. Monitor seconds using the Satellite Clock.
20 seconds after this, an audible tone warns that the retrograde engine is about to fire. Remember that you can silcene the alarm if you wish.
The retrograde engines will then fire 20 seconds after the warning tone.

The retrograde engines will fire one at a time. Retro engine No.1 will immediately fire, 5 seconds after the No.2 engine will fire, and then 5 seconds after No. 2 has fired, No. 3 will fire. Each engine will burn for about 10 seconds.

Ignition! All three retro engines will now fire one at a time. Use the Satellite Clock to count the seconds. Again, there is a 5 second delay between each engine ignition, each burning for 10 seconds.
Complete the checklist and skip the last "Start RETRO checklist" step using the checkmark.
Next we will need to jettison the retrograde engines. We do not want to bring them with us through the atmosphere. RUN the Mission Pad -> Checklists -> Entry: RE-ENTRY checklist.
This checklist will arm the retro jettison squibs and configure the fuse needed to allow retro jettison. Continue with the checklist until the retrograde engines are jettisoned.

There goes the retrograde engines! Good job. The next part will configure the ASCS to manever to REENTRY attitude as we did earlier. Continue with the checklist to position the craft for REENTRY attitude.

When the capsule detects an atmospheric drag of 0.05G, the entry begins. At this point the craft will start to roll and go through the atmosphere. Use a low timescale setting until this is detected, it should happen at around 1 hours and 40 minutes on the mission timer. Timescale will automatically stop at this time.
Okay, the capsule is now touching the atmosphere and entry will shortly begin. Press CLEAR ALL to complete the checklist.
Next we are going to hit the atmosphere and the G's will start to build. Let the capsule fly through the upper atmosphere for a couple of minutes.
Ok, the G's are building fast now. At this point, open the Mission Pad -> Checklists -> Entry: LANDING checklist. We will just reference it in this lesson.
Most of the entry is automatic and your job is to monitor the G-load and altitude. The ASCS will take you through the atmosphere.

Ok, we are through. Let us take a look at the checklist. The first thing it wants it to connect EMER DROGUE DEPLOY fuse. This should already be set, and will allow you to deploy the drogue manually if needed.
At 21.000 ft, the drogue will automatically deploy.
After this, the snorkel will automatically open, this will bring fresh air into the cabin and equalize the pressure with outside.
The EMER O2 will also flow, and you can silence the alarm. This brings oxygen at a high fixes rate through the cabin.
Next up is the Main Chutes. It will also automatically deploy at 10.800 ft.
Mains are out! At this point the RCS fuel will automatically dump, and the landing bag will extend. The landing bag is a "pillow" used to soften our impact with the water.
The fuel warning light will illuminated, be sure to silence it.
The next event is to splash down into the ocean.
Excellent, we now have impact and splash down! Reentry using the ASCS together with the sequencer and programmer will make entry mostly an automated sequence.
This completes the lesson.

Title: Tutorial 7 - The Sequencer, Retrograde burn, and Landing
Description: The Sequencer (aka. The Pprogrammer) is what controls what stage/phase of the mission you are in, from launch to reentry and landing. In this lesson we will learn how it works. We will then use it to perform a retrograde burn with a splashdown in the Atlantic ocean.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

The Sequencer (referred to as the "Programmer") is responsible for controlling what phase of the mission you are in. It will detect when events such as the tower jettison, the capsule separation, initial atmospheric drag, perform retrograde burn, and the deployment of the drogue and main chutes to safely land in the ocean.
